div.p: Greetings. You have written to me, dearest brother Hieronymus, a most bitter and quite different letter than I would have expected from an elder and from one free from youthful passions. You rail against Ulmius, although he seems to have neither sinned against you nor against the brothers.

Indeed, he has never made any mention of you to me except in an honorable way. However, I know what happens when minds are divided; Satan joins in with unrestrained tongues and kindles sparks of a future fire, and does not cease until the fire grows immensely. Therefore, I urge you, my brother, to remember that Pauline, I mean apostolic, saying: Be angry, and do not sin; do not let the sun go down on your wrath, nor give place to the devil. I know you have suffered something human here. Return to your spirit (friend?) and embrace in our Lord.
You will understand more from the faithful minister of the Steckborn church, dear brother, and from public letters. I love you, my Hieronymus, and I wish you and yours to be very well in Christ.
To the most beloved man, Mr. Hieronymus Kranz, his most esteemed and dearest lord and brother. Diessenhofen.
